instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2849: What is 820-2849? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPVCORE_GPU: What is PPVCORE_GPU? This is the main power rail for the GPU. This is required for the GPU to turn on so you can get image on the display. .
definitions.U8900: What is U8900? This chip creates the GPU power rails on the 820-3332 board to the 2012 and early 2013 15‚Äù Retina Macbook Pros. It becomes desoldered and is the cause of no video and kernel panics/crashes in that model most of the time..
definitions.C9560: What is C9560? Tantalum capacitor on 820-2850 logic board that often dies and causes intermittent power to framebuffer PP1V8R1V55_S0GPU_ISNS and PP1V8R1V55_S0GPU_ISNS_R rail, causing GPU kernel panics. Replace with non-tantalum if machine is having random black screen or kernel panics.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2849</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power cycling, missing <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_GPU</SIGNAL>
threads.message: This <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2849</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Turns on for 5 seconds, off for 5 seconds and repeats this over and over again. If its on every Rail except <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_GPU</SIGNAL> is present. <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_GPU</SIGNAL> is 0.05V. <CHIP>U8900</CHIP> seems to have all signals it needs and i get ~6 Ohms to GND on it. Is that to low? Is there anything i forgot to check or is it the GPU? From my experience with the 15" 2010 models i know these Nvidia GPUs as normally reliable - not only in comparison with the 2011 AMD ones...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2849</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power cycling, missing <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_GPU</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Did you try known good BIOS?

You should expect <CAPACITOR>C9560</CAPACITOR> failure, before Nvidia.
Seems that is not the case here.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2849</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power cycling, missing <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_GPU</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Thank you. I saved the original file and flashed one i downloaded from badcaps. Unfortunately nothing changed.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2849</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power cycling, missing <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_GPU</SIGNAL>
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2849</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power cycling, missing <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_GPU</SIGNAL>
threads.message: I never hat a bad <CHIP>U8900</CHIP> but in this case it seems top have done the trick. Now it turns on and boots. Only problem is that i cant get an image on the screen. LVDS connector looks a little bend inside and i have seen this causing no image before if its not making good contact. Right noe i have no 40 pin connectors in stock or on donors so ill need to wait until they arrive. I come back to this if i changed the connector.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2849</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power cycling, missing <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_GPU</SIGNAL>
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2849</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power cycling, missing <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_GPU</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Yes and it did not work. But i had problems with my HDMI adapter recently (unfortunately i cant trust it 100%) and the pins in the LVDS look out of place and the cable won't go in easily. So i want to be sure that the connection is working. Screen dosen't do anything. No Light, no image. So i assumed its not properly detected (have seen this before)... Also if i wait long enought voice over starts talking to me so i am sure its completely booted into my install USB.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2849</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power cycling, missing <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_GPU</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Update: LVDS arrived and device is now working fine. Old one came off the board really easy - was not original. Ill flash the original Bios back on it and it should be fixed. Thank you very much - mark as solved please.
